data.text:
Parking in Tofino

A Decrease font size. A Reset font size. A Increase font size.

Pay Parking

The District of Tofino offers a variety of parking options, including unrestricted and pay-to-park zones, to cater to the needs of both residents and visitors. Each location has clear signage that provides information on parking regulations and any restrictions that apply. The District urges all drivers to pay close attention to these signs to comply with local rules and avoid any fines.

For more details on the various parking options throughout the District of Tofino, click the boxes below to navigate to the applicable parking zone.

Downtown Pay Parking

Downtown Pay Parking is in effect daily from 9 AM to 6 PM, from May 1 through October 31.

The District of Tofino encourages all visitors and residents to carefully observe all posted parking signs and restrictions when visiting the downtown core.

Free parking is available from 6 to 9 AM and 6 to 11 PM year round. Overnight parking is prohibited.

Downtown has sections of time-restricted parking that offer free parking for 15 minutes to 2 hours, available all year round.

Residents and visitors are encouraged to use alternative modes of transportation, such as biking, walking, and public transit, instead of driving and parking in the downtown core when possible.

Residents

Tofino, Tla-o-qui-aht, Ahousaht, and Hesquiaht residents can gain free access at Downtown Pay Parking locations by registering for an annual Beach Pay Parking permit.

Ucluelet and other Alberni Clayoquot Regional District (ACRD) community residents qualify for a 50% discount on this annual pass.

Figure out what parking permit you need with this guide.

Register: tofino.robbinsparking.com

*Please note* The Municipal Hall lots are not included in the free residents' permit for Downtown Pay Parking.

Downtown Residents

Downtown residents can register for a resident decal to park on their block long-term and overnight. Each residence unit is eligible for 1 decal for free and a 2nd decal for $150. Decals must be renewed annually before May 1.

To receive your Downtown Resident Decal:

Visit the Municipal Hall during operating hours.

Bring ID and proof of address of your residence that is on or adjacent to a downtown pay parking location

Figure out what parking permit you need with this guide.

Visitors

Downton Pay Parking is in effect every day from 9 AM - 6 PM until May 1 to October 31 every year. Please obey the signage in the area you have parked.

Ways to Pay

Visitors can pay for Downtown Pay Parking one of three ways including:

Meter: Pay with coins or credit cards at nearby physical pay meters.

Honk Mobile: Download the Honk Mobile app to pay with your smartphone

PayByPhone: Visit the PayByPhone website or call 1-888-680-7275 with location & payment details.

Rates

Type of Vehicle Rate Personal Vehicles $2.50 per hour Recreational Vehicles (RV) $5 per hour Commercial Vehicles $120 Annual

Municipal Hall Lots

Municipal Hall pay parking is in effect from May through October of each year in the parking lots adjacent to the Municipal Hall at 121 Third Street.

Vehicles over 20 feet and trailers are not permitted in these parking lots at any time.

*Please note* Parking at the Municipal Hall is not included in the free residents' permit for Downtown Pay Parking.

Length Rate 2 Hours $5 12 Hours $12.50 24 Hours $15.50 7 Days $44 14 Days $81

Beach Pay Parking

Beach Pay Parking is enforced daily from 8 AM to 11 PM throughout the year at all District of Tofino beach access points, including Mackenzie Beach, Chesterman Beach, and Cox Bay. This applies to dedicated parking lots and marked roadside parking in these areas.

The District of Tofino urges all visitors and residents to carefully observe all posted parking signs and restrictions when visiting the beach.

Residents and visitors are encouraged to use alternative modes of transportation, such as biking, walking, and public transit, instead of driving and parking to beach accesses when possible.

Residents

Tofino, Tla-o-qui-aht, Ahousaht, and Hesquiaht residents can get a free annual Beach Pay Parking permit. These permits also give residents free access to applicable Downtown Pay Parking zones.

Ucluelet and other Alberni Clayoquot Regional District (ACRD) community residents qualify for a 50% discount on this annual pass.

Register: tofino.robbinsparking.com

Residents renewing their annual pass must do so by October 31 each year.

Visitors

Beach Pay Parking is in effect from 8 AM to 11 PM throughout the year at all District of Tofino beach access points.

Ways to Pay

Visitors can pay for Beach Pay Parking one of three ways including:

Meter: Pay with coins or credit cards at nearby physical pay meters.

Honk Mobile: Download the Honk Mobile app to pay with your smartphone

PayByPhone: Visit the PayByPhone website or call 1-888-680-7275 with location & payment details.

Rates

Rate Hourly $3 per hour Daily $15 per day Annual $150 Annual Monthly Frank Island Overnight Parking $60 Monthly Lynn/Chesterman Beach Road Overnight Guest Parking $24 Nightly

Offshore Parking

Eligible residents of offshore communities can obtain annual parking permits for vehicle parking within the District of Tofino. These permits can be acquired from the Municipal Hall and are valid in specially designated parking areas and stalls reserved for offshore permit holders.

Please note - Offshore Parking permits do not allow vehicles to be parked beyond posted time limits, in pay lots without an applicable permit, or in assigned parking areas for Tla-o-qui-aht First Nation. Click below for further Rules & Regulations.

Qualifying for a Permit

To qualify for a permit, offshore residents must provide:

A current licence plate number; and

Proof of offshore residency* (current vehicle insurance documents or a current driver’s licence)

Visitors and persons who do not have a permanent offshore address do not qualify for parking permits.

Other Forms of Proof Include: Current Lease or Purchase Agreements; Recent Telephone, Cable or Utility Bills; Recent Credit Card or Bank Statements.

Applying on Someone Else's Behalf: Please bring all necessary documentation noted above.

Contractors/Temporary Offshore Workers: Offshore communities have been issued limited permits for temporary contractors/workers. Please get in touch with the administration office for the relevant community for more information about obtaining a temporary permit while working offshore.

Offshore Permit Only Spaces

Offshore Permit Only parking spaces are available on a first-come, first-served basis. Having a permit does not guarantee a space.

If no Offshore Permit spaces are available, permit holders may park:

In any of the unrestricted parking areas throughout the District.

In time-limited parking spots, but only for the time specified.

In Pay Parking lots for the prescribed fee.

Rules and Regulations

There is no fee for Offshore Parking permits.

Permits must be visibly displayed – hung face-out on the rear-view mirror.

Permits are valid for one calendar year, from January 1 to December 31, and allow parking in permit-designated spots for unlimited time.

Permits are not valid for unattached boat trailers.

Permits are issued to license plates registered to a specific person; they are not transferable.

Offshore Parking Map

Click to View: Offshore Parking Map

This map displays all Offshore Parking areas, including areas specifically designated for Tla-o-qui-aht First Nation parking.

Offshore Parking Background Information

PARKING CHALLENGES: Due to increasing population growth in all communities located in Clayoquot Sound, the Downtown Pay Parking program was implemented by the District of Tofino in 2023 to manage long-standing parking and traffic challenges downtown. The parking program includes a mix of free, paid, and offshore parking spaces.

RECONCILIATION: Historically, there have been about 140 parking spaces assigned to offshore residents. Of those spaces, around 40 are assigned to the Tla-o-qui-aht First Nation (as of 2023). This designation comes after extensive conversations between the District of Tofino and Tla-o-qui-aht First Nation on matters regarding reconciliation. The designation of these parking spaces recognizes Tla-o-qui-aht First Nation’s traditional territory.

WORKING TOGETHER: The District of Tofino regularly meets with the leadership of both Tla-o-qui-aht First Nation and Ahousaht First Nation to discuss parking challenges. Finding a lasting solution will likely require involvement from higher levels of government, beyond our local government. As communities continue to grow, parking challenges will only worsen without new land development.

TAKING ACTION

The District of Tofino is currently working towards the following in regards to offshore parking:

A covered shelter will be installed at First Street Dock with seating and temporary storage. Estimated Completion: Late 2024/Early 2025

Designated parking for Tla-o-qui-aht, Ahousaht, and Hesquiaht elders with valid Offshore Parking permits will be offered on First Street, between Main Street and the First Street Dock. A new stairway will soon provide improved access to the dock. Estimated Completion: Late 2024/Early 2025

A transit stop has been installed at First Street & Main Street to allow for closer bus access to offshore parking: Completed Summer 2024

12 additional Offshore Parking spaces located on Gibson Street were added. Completed Spring 2024

District staff will continue to work with partners from all levels of government to bring parking solutions to the downtown core. Ongoing

Offshore Parking Contacts

Tla-o-qui-aht First Nation: 250-725-3350

Ahousaht First Nation: ​250-670-9563

Hesquiaht First Nation: 250-670-1122

Pay Parking FAQs

In the past, parking congestion at Tofino's beaches and downtown core has negatively impacted the experience of both visitors and residents. Informal and poor parking habits frequently resulted in degraded road safety, infrastructure damage, high enforcement needs and reduced parking convenience and access.

In 2021, the District of Tofino committed to improving public parking layout and design to address this issue. Beach and Downtown pay parking was introduced to cover the costs related to parking, including the dedicated enforcement resources. Up until now, parking-related costs have been funded by taxation.

Pay Parking is a proven method to increase parking availability in publicly used spaces, which provides more opportunities for shared access to public assets. Parking revenues also offer a new and important funding source for programs, services, and facilities benefiting the community.

No. Municipalities are prohibited from assisting businesses under section 25 of the Community Charter. Providing a free parking pass for a business-owned vehicle would violate this rule. However, business owners can pay for hourly, day, and annual passes, and parking receipts can be recorded as business expenses.

Parking passes can be purchased at the pay stations or via the online parking apps highlighted on the pay parking signage throughout the community.

Annual commercial passes can be purchased in person at the Municipal Hall at 121 Third Street.

Revenues from parking throughout Tofino (including beach and downtown pay parking) go towards the District's Pay Parking Reserve Fund, which helps to fund various initiatives throughout the District, including:

Recreation Facilities & Equipment

Roads, Sidewalks and MUP Infrastructure

Parks Facilities

Transit

Customers can pay and manage their parking needs via the parking meter (credit card or coin payment), via digital apps such as Honk Mobile App, Pay By Phone App and also payment through a 1-800 number listed on the parking signage.

Campbell Street is a provincial highway under the jurisdiction of the Ministry of Transportation and Infrastructure (MOTI), and it is not included in Downtown Pay Parking.

Campbell Street does have free time-limited parking available.

All available parking spaces are on a first-come, first-served basis.

Overnight street parking is not permitted except for downtown residents with a permit and displayed vehicle decal.

Overnight camping in any vehicle throughout the District of Tofino is not permitted at any time.

The Municipal Hall lots are designed for long-term parking.

Residents with a free Downtown Pay Parking permit who can not park at their place of business are encouraged to park on Gibson Street and side streets. The goal is to free up parking availability nearest Campbell Street so that residents and visitors can have easier access to local businesses.

A Downtown Pay Parking permit cannot be used to park at the Municipal Hall lots. Separate payment is required if parking at these lots.

It is recommended that those who work in the downtown area consider alternative modes of transportation such as biking, walking, or taking public transit.

No, the Pacific Rim National Park Reserve has its own pay parking system.

Yes, the decals that downtown residents receive, allowing them to park on their street, are renewed annually and must be collected from the Municipal Hall prior to May 1 each year.
